title: 115_hr4121
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Development Lab Act of 2017". The Global Development Lab Act of 2017 emphasizes enhancing foreign assistance through innovation, science, and technology to address development challenges and promote economic growth in developing countries. The USAID's Office of Science and Technology and Office of Innovation were merged into the United States Global Development Lab in 2014. The United States Global Development Lab partners with various organizations to find solutions to development challenges in a faster and more sustainable way. They use a competitive innovation incentive awards model to select and test ideas with the greatest potential for success. Enhancing the authorities supporting this model will help the Lab diversify and expand the sources of ideas. The United States Global Development Lab aims to expand the number and sources of ideas to address development challenges, increasing opportunities for applying cost-effective solutions. The United States Global Development Lab aims to expand ideas for addressing development challenges. The United States Global Development Lab, established in USAID, focuses on utilizing science, technology, innovation, and partnerships to develop solutions to end extreme poverty. Its duties include discovering, testing, and scaling development innovations, leveraging resources of various organizations, organizing innovation-driven competitions, and supporting USAID missions and bureaus. The United States Global Development Lab, part of USAID, uses science, technology, innovation, and partnerships to address extreme poverty. It supports missions and bureaus in decision-making, procurement, and program design. The Administrator has authorities to provide innovation awards and use funds for innovation initiatives from 2018 to 2022. The Administrator of the United States Global Development Lab has the authority to employ up to 30 individuals on a limited term basis from 2018 to 2022. They can also require recipients of funding to return program income attributable to them. The Administrator of the United States Global Development Lab can employ up to 30 individuals on a limited term basis from 2018 to 2022 and may require recipients to return program income linked to the funding received. The returned program income can be credited back to the account used for the grant, contract, or cooperative agreement. Amounts returned and credited to an account under the grant, contract, or cooperative agreement shall be merged with other funds in the account and made available, subject to appropriation, for the same purposes and period of time as other funds in the account. The account funds are available for Lab programs and activities. Amounts returned cannot be used for employment. The Administrator must provide a detailed accounting of USAID's use of authorities annually. The Administrator must provide a detailed accounting of USAID's use of authorities annually, including sources, amounts, and uses of funding. Innovation incentive awards are limited to $100,000 per award and 10 awards in total for fiscal year 2018. Congressional committees must be notified within 15 days of each award. Staff should aim to exercise authority under paragraph (1)(B). The Administrator should ensure that any increase in staff at the Lab is balanced by a reduction in staff elsewhere in USAID. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like Administrator (referring to the head of USAID), appropriate congressional committees, Lab (referring to the Global Development Lab), USAID, and innovation incentive award. An "incentive award" provides competitive funding to encourage solutions for specific problems related to poverty alleviation or to promote a wide range of ideas for further development by third parties.
